awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Examining Prospective Secondary Mathematics Teachers Learning to Use Curriculum Materials to Plan and Enact Instruction
awd_abstract_narration:
There are a growing number of curriculum resources available to secondary mathematics teachers and most teachers use curriculum materials in mathematics instruction. This project will investigate how to help pre-service teachers use mathematics curriculum materials purposefully to plan and to teach. A focus of this work is curricular noticing or how teachers interpret and respond to curriculum resources. A component of helping pre-service teachers prepare for the classroom is helping them understand how to effectively and purposefully use the tools that have been provided to them. The study includes data collected from experienced teachers and pre-service teachers as well as the design of resources for mathematics teacher educators. A significant component is studying what teachers notice when reviewing curriculum and planning for teaching. This work has implications for the design of curriculum materials and for teacher education. This project is supported by NSF's EHR Core Research (ECR) program. The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field. The Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) program is a National Science Foundation (NSF)-wide activity that offers awards in support of junior faculty who exemplify the role of teacher-scholars through outstanding research, excellent education, and the integration of education and research within the context of the mission of their organizations.

The study has five research and educational objectives related to curricular noticing. First, to understand how to define the curricular noticing practices of attending to, interpreting, and deciding to respond to curriculum materials so that they are useful to research and teaching. Second, to understand what kinds of experiences best reveal the curricular noticing practices. Third, to understand and document the curricular noticing practices of practicing teachers. Fourth, to understand and document the curricular noticing practices of prospective teachers during and beyond teacher preparation. Fifth, to develop a module to support prospective teachers learning of the curricular noticing practice. To accomplish these goals, the study will incorporate interviews with experienced teachers and prospective teachers and conduct classroom observations. Some interviews will include eye-tracking technology to interpret what teachers attend to when looking at materials for planning. For the prospective teachers, a longitudinal approach will be used to investigate their curricular noticing during their preparation program and into their first years of teaching. From an education standpoint, the project will also include the creation of resources for other mathematics teacher preparation programs and courses to use. The project also includes professional development in curriculum use for secondary mathematics teachers.

por.por_cntn:
The project CAREER: Curricular Noticing: Examining Prospective Secondary Mathematics Teachers Learning to Attend to, Interpret, and Decide to Respond to Curriculum Materials focused on understanding how prospective 6-12 mathematics teachers learn to use curriculum materails in purposeful ways to plan and enact instruction. Specifically, the project aimed to understand how curricular noticing practices (attention to curriculum, interpretations of curriculum, and responses to curriculum), influence prospective teachers planned and enacted lessons.

Across the project, data was collected from twelve teachers using a variety of methods including staged planning interviews, plan-teach-reflect cycles, and task-based interviews. When engaged in these methods, when planning teachers were asked to wear eye tracking glasses to capture eye gaze (i.e., attention) and to talk aloud so that the researchers could gain insight into their decisions (i.e., interpretations and responses).

Findings from this study have led to a greater understanding of how prospective teachers use curriculum materials and what we might do to better support them in learning to use curriculum materials during teacher preparation. Specifically, findings indicated that what teachers attended to (or did not attend to) impacted their planned and enacted lessons. Although this finding may seem obvious the eye tracking data provided empirical evidence for what exactly teachers looked at and did not look at. The aspects of curriculum materails that were not attended to, such as particular tasks and our suggestions in teacher materials, were not included in lesson plans and therefore did not appear in enacted lessons. In addition, the format of the materails and the resources used by teachers when planning (e.g., lesson planning templates) influenced what and how they attended to their materails. Materails that included teacher suggestions within the context of student tasks were attended to more thoroughly (i.e., reading from start to finish) whereas materials that had suggestions wrapped around tasks and not directly connected to the task resulted in teachers attending more sporadically (i.e., moving quickly from one thing to the next). Finally, findings indicated that the resources used during planning impacted attention. For example, when teachers had a planning template, they often searched the materails for particular apsects that the template asked for (e.g., goals) whereas when they did not have such a template they often attended more to the materails from start to finish.

Findings also suggested the value of capturing attention when studying how teachers use curriculum materails. From a methodological perspective without seeing what teachers attended to it was difficult to make sense of how they were using the materails. However, when we captured attention through their eye gaze, we were able to make more reliable inferences about their interpretations and responses to curriculum materials.

Results from this study have been used to design modules for teachers to learn to use curriculum materails, particularly focused on supporting their attention. These modules include familiarizing teachers with what curriculum materails are, introducing them explicitly to the curricular noticing practices, and engaging them with a wide variety of curriculum materails so that they can learn to attend to important aspects regardless of format.
